title: Anyone else feel like champs aren't buffed/nerfed equally? ( Hear me out)
body:
Riot is so slow to nerf vayne, but quick on the trigger for other champs

Things like Evelynn gets nerfed out of the blue, but season long god tier vayne is untouchable.

Then we have the love tap buffs/nerfs to champs like MF, but huge sweeping buffs/nerfs to champs like skarner

Finally we have obscure rarely seen champs like galio that don't even get attention from devs. 

People say galio exists solely to counter full AP teams. That's not a champion identity so much as it sounds like the role of an item

This thread is the same shit people have been miming like lemmings all over the forums constantly, and frankly, I'm glad Riot doesn't listen to most of you morons.  There are always going to be balance problems; LoL is a growing game and it's difficult to balance an increasingly large roster of champions against each other.  But spamming threads about how Vayne is OP, which Riot is well aware of, doesn't take into consideration the fact that they might be working on it without further upsetting the balance of the game or trying to approach its balance indirectly.  Certain champions being powerful at certain points in the game's life time aren't always because of the flat numbers, sometimes it's because their lane counters are particularly weak at the moment, or certain itemization options that favor them are more powerful, and that opens up an entire web of balance that Riot cannot simply balance directly or carelessly lest they make a mess of things even more.

Be patient, smarten up, and look to your own game.  This thread mentions Galio has no place in the game, and a lot of people say that Zac and Aatrox are woefully underpowered or out of place, but I've climbed my way to Diamond playing largely those 3 champions among a few other odd balls.  Stop being so concerned with what is and what isn't OP or FOTM and just play what you want and try to get good at it, and you'll get some where.

In the meanwhile, I'm sure Riot is going to work on these things.  They're not some maniacal moustache twirling Vayne mains that drum their fingers together and laugh in ecstasy at people dying to Vayne, it's in their best interest to work these things out eventually.

I think I remember seeing a post a few days ago about how Riot doesn't nerf the top tier champions and will instead nerf the second and third tier champions so that, when they get around to nerfing the top tier, the second and third tier wont be there to instantly become top tier. The level of stupidity in such a process is mind boggling to say the least because there will ALWAYS be a second and third tier under the first, regardless of how good the champs in it are. All doing the above accomplishes is letting the top tier reign supreme to an even greater degree because now the somewhat good champions you might use to try to even the scales have been nerfed.

For a game this large with so many champions and items, the only real solution Riot has is to use a "water-wheel" sort of balancing process where they just continually adjust champion power based on what becomes "OP" after their last round of changes. The only alternative would be to make absolutely no changes to items/champions for a prolonged period of time and then release a massive rebalancing patch to try to get EVERY champion into a balanced state. Of course, doing such is pretty implausible, especially considering the LCS level of play they have to manage, but it is still technically an option.

Strategy, item building, and resource management are typically being sidelined in favor of raw champion kits and reflex. Champions that Riot believes are fun to watch are prioritized above and beyond champions that are fun to play. 

Riot has a real beef with Mages and Assassins (built as such) recently, as they deal burst damage. They can be extraordinarily fun and risky to play, but teamfights become shorter, yes? Not as much action in LC$.

"Counterplay" has become a word used to justify changes, not make them. Counterplay no longer means "behaviors in the game meant to reduce the impact of present or anticipated enemy action" as much as it means "things you can do to negate what your opponent _just did,_ making no assumptions about your champion choice, positioning, or items." The power of items has been devalued. Riot's justification for Fiora's ultimate doing % max health burst damage was, 

"[it] allows her to threaten bulkier ones without having an unfair advantage against the more fragile. If it dealt %HP physical damage instead, the number would have to be much larger to scratch through a tank's armor, and that same number would mean instant death to unarmored opponents."

This basically says, "we want Fiora to be able to engage targets regardless of role, items, or armor." It devalues all anticipatory play and seeks to justify putting the entire outcome of a fight on the way each player plays exclusively during the moments of actual engagement. It's a total rejection of strategy.

League of Legends is changing from a game into a spectator sport. Administrative policy is pushing the game away from a contest of strategy, positioning, and resource management, into a contest of fine motor control and reflex. Which has many people upset because this new League barely resembles the game that attracted them to begin with. 

These attitudes are reflected in every level of development including champion balance. If it's not flashy and widely visible, they simply don't care as much.
I find this even funnier because they fail to realize that if they alienate their playerbase, they have no one for the pros to actually recruit.

Riot's decision-making on champion changes is 110% biased and < 1% based on real balance issues and logic.

My own feelings on the champions you mentioned just for your pleasure so you can contrast it with how you feel about them and see what I mean:

I don't think Eve is toxic or should be made unviable (and neither does Riot from what I've seen). But that's just my opinion on the matter. I've only barely played her, don't play against her that often, and she seems fine in the high tier and pro games I watch. ~~The latest PBE nerf seems a little unnecessary to me but not that big anyways.~~  Oh look I just checked and the latest PBE changes include reverting that nerf. PBE is PBE.

I agreed with Riot on the energy return change for Lee as a fellow Lee scrub (I don't even own him). The ult buff seemed tiny but not really needed. Overall a pretty small impact, especially at high tier play.

Galio is a weird situation to me because I think he's actually quite good. However he has kit issues that make him a little worse as skill and coordination of the enemy go up, making it very unlikely for him to see high tier play. Also he's really hard to play well, especially early on because his mana is rough at first. Combined these two factors leave him in an awkward spot where he's OP at low tier play but only in the hands of people who main him. But if Riot makes his mana less of an issue in the early game he gets really annoying to play against for lower tier players. So how to change him? And does he really need changes? I'm not sure he does. They did in fact buff him twice this season as well, though not greatly. I could see his E costing 60-80 mana instead of the 70-90 it does now though. Currently using it early at all is usually a mistake.

I don't think Vayne is a big problem right now. I know the stats. Blah blah stats are skewed, partially self perpetuating bs anyways. The main thing is Blade of the Ruined King is too good and Vayne is annoying to deal with. I think if they just cut the stealth on her ult + tumbles in half and nerf BotRK a little she'd be fine. It's hard to cc her when you can't see her.

Shen was a little too good. I think they're trying to make his laning and split pushing a little less safe as well as take away some of his hidden power in team fights. Seems reasonable. He got some hefty buffing earlier this season and has seen a lot of pro play since.

As long as they're done right I'm ok with some Syndra buffs. They just gotta be real careful. Her mid game is good and with all the bug fixes a lot more consistent now. I wish her play style was a little less binary but whatever. And that's from someone who currently gets facerolled by Syndra. Man I gotta learn how to play vs her better. If they buff her enough elsewhere they should increase the cd on her ult a little, it's rather low for a point and click nuke.

Some champions SHOULD be kept away from the competitive scene that's for sure. Some of them are toxic or retarded. Fair point. 

But it doesn't mean that the game can stay as biased as it is now : this state is not acceptable . In casual  and semi-serious (ranked  & high elo ranked) play, those things matter more than ever. 

Do you remember the days ( late season 2 and the entire season 3 basically) where Riot tuned down rengar so much that he wouldn't even be playable in normal games lol. This is the typical example of what Riot is capable of. The cat was basically a trash champion with like 40% win rate or something like that. 

**So in the end, the problem is that if you want to win games, you HAVE TO be on Riot's side as far as balance goes. **
